results.title: Alma de Groen
results.creator_credit: Otrun Zuber-Skerrit and Television Unit, University of Queensland
results.brief_description:
Episode number 6 of Series “Australian playwrights speak”.
Alma De Groen is one of Australia’s most innovative and challenging playwrights. This interview offers an enlightening introduction to her work. She speaks about her early plays and the emergence of her interest in the outsider figure, feminism, and developments in her latest work. She also discusses the inspiration she seeks from the work of visual artists for the form and style of her plays. Interviewed by Elizabeth Perkins.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Otrun Zuber-Skerrit and Television Unit, University of Queensland

results.title: Stephen Sewell
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Australian playwrights speak”.
Stephen Sewell’s plays have often aroused considerable controversy over their moral and political exploration. He discusses the influence of his Catholic, working-class background on his work.

results.title: Something shining
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Australian mosaic”.
Something shining tells the story of a young pilot, Frederick Valentich, who disappeared with his small plane over Bass Strait as he returned from a flight to King Island. His enigmatic message of sighting “something shining” just before he disappeared has led many, including his parents, to believe he was captured by a UFO.

results.title: Chinese Diggers
results.creator_credit: Teck Tan, Margaret Smith and SBS-TV
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Australian mosaic”.
A Prizewinner at the 31st International Film and TV Festival of New York this program looks at Australia’s attitude to Chinese Australians who wanted to join the Armed Forces to assist in the defence of Australia during the Second World War. In examining the stories of those interviewed a number of issues are brought to light. The video is accompanied by Teacher’s notes and workcards.
results.description:

results.title: The Tempest in Bali
results.creator_credit: Ugo Mariotti, Barbara Mariotti and SBS-TV
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Australian mosaic”.
In 1988 a group of students from Murdoch University under the leadership of David George and Serge Tampalini staged a production of Shakespeare’s “The Tempest” in Bali during the monsoon. The program documents the various bureaucratic problems they encountered and the assimilation of Balinese dance, music and shadow puppets into the production.
results.description:

results.title: Skin of the earth
results.creator_credit: Frank Rijavec, Film and Television Institute (W.A.) and Excalibur Nominees
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Australian mosaic”.
John Thomson, a retired forester from Western Australia, and a committed conservationist gives his view on the destruction of the Karri forests and the subsequent effects on the land in Western Australia. His views are reiterated by Norman Lockyer, a farmer and by Dr. Chittleborough who failed in his attempt to put through a comprehensive State Conservation Strategy. Although largely pessimistic in its outlook the program does suggest that attitudes are changing to the hitherto wasteful and destructive forestry and agricultural practices.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Frank Rijavec, Film and Television Institute (W.A.) and Excalibur Nominees

results.title: Paying our dues
results.creator_credit: Ruth Cullen, Georgia Allen and SBS-TV
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Australian mosaic”.
Trade unions in Australia are very much Anglo-Saxon male dominated. Migrant women wanting to participate in the labour movement have sexual, language and cultural barriers to overcome and very little is being done to rectify this situation. In this program various women speak about their situation; factory workers and outworkers contribute their opinion about the difficulties in getting what they need out of their union.

results.title: A meeting of ways
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Australian mosaic”.
Describes the process of organising a community art project for a newly-opened community centre in Melbourne called Ross House. This program records the joys, the frustrations, the tears, the highs and the lows in the making of community art.
results.description:
Episode of Series “Australian mosaic”.

results.title: The Big gamble
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Australian mosaic”.
Australians per capita are the biggest gamblers in the world. This program takes a valuable look at how, when, why and where Australians love to have a bet.
results.description:
Episode of Series “Australian mosaic”.
Australians per capita are the biggest gamblers in the world. This program takes a valuable look at how, when, why and where Australians love to have a bet.

results.title: Cross currents (A)
results.creator_credit: Erika Jakubassa, Georgia Allen and SBS-TV
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Australian mosaic”.
This video examines the problems encountered by Aborigines and overseas born Australians when dealing with the health care system. Health care professionals discuss the importance of providing interpreting services, of the need for cross-cultural communication training, and the need for health services to encourage the employment of staff from a variety of cultural backgrounds. The video dramatises some of the drastic consequences of doctors and health professionals not communicating effectively with patients from other cultural backgrounds.

The video dramatises some of the drastic consequences of doctors and health professionals not communicating effectively with patients from other cultural backgrounds.

This video examines the problems encountered by Aborigines and overseas born Australians when dealing with the health care system. Health care professionals discuss the importance of providing interpreting services, of the need for cross-cultural communication training, and the need for health services to encourage the employment of staff from a variety of cultural backgrounds. The video dramatises some of the drastic consequences of doctors and health professionals not communicating effectively with patients from other cultural backgrounds.
